question:
Who among the following was the President of the Belgaum Session of the Indian National Congress held in 1924?

SSC CGL 23/09/2024 (1st Shift)
solution:
• The Belgaum Session of the Indian National Congress was held in 1924.
  • Mahatma Gandhi presided over this session.
  • This was the only session of the Indian National Congress ever presided over by Mahatma Gandhi.
  • It was significant as it marked a rare instance of Gandhi engaging in organizational politics directly.
  • The session focused on national unity, khadi promotion, and constructive programmes.

Additional Information:

  • The Indian National Congress was founded in 1885.
  • The first session was held in Bombay under W.C. Bonnerjee.
  • Subhas Chandra Bose presided over sessions in Haripura (1938) and Tripuri (1939).
  • Jawaharlal Nehru presided over the Lahore Session (1929) where Purna Swaraj was declared.
  • Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel was President of the Indian National Congress in 1931 at the Karachi Session.

question:
Where was the 1912 session of the India National Congress held in Bihar?

SSC CGL 24/09/2024 (2nd Shift)
solution:
• The 1912 session of the Indian National Congress was held at Bankipore, a locality in Patna, Bihar.
  • This session was presided over by Raghuveer Narayan.
  • Bankipore was an important administrative and political center in British-era Bihar.
  • The session focused on political reforms and increasing Indian participation in governance after the 1911 transfer of the capital from Calcutta to Delhi.

Additional Information:

  • 1911 marked the shift of the British Indian capital from Calcutta to Delhi.
  • Bankipore later became a prominent hub of nationalist activities in Bihar.
  • Other major INC sessions in Bihar:
    • Gaya (1922) – presided by C.R. Das.
    • Patna (1934) – presided by Rajendra Prasad.
  • Saharsa and Madhubani were not venues for any INC session during the freedom movement.

question:
Who amongst the following became the president of the second session of the Indian National Congress held in Calcutta in December 1886 ?

SSC CPO 28/06/2024 (1st shift)
solution:
• The second session of the Indian National Congress was held in Calcutta in December 1886.
  • It was presided over by Dadabhai Naoroji, a prominent Parsi leader and economic thinker.
  • He was the first Indian to formally demand Swaraj (self-government) from the British.
  • Known as the “Grand Old Man of India”, Naoroji highlighted the Drain of Wealth theory to explain British economic exploitation.

Additional Information:

  • First INC session (1885) was held in Bombay under W.C. Bonnerjee.
  • Dadabhai Naoroji later became INC President three times: 1886 (Calcutta), 1893 (Lahore), and 1906 (Calcutta).
  • P Ananda Charlu was a prominent early Congress worker but never became INC president.
  • Badruddin Tyabji was the third INC President (Madras session, 1887).
  • William Wedderburn presided over the Allahabad session (1888) and Bombay session (1893).

question:
The Indian National Congress formally took up the Swadeshi call in its Banaras session of 1905 under the presidentship of _________.

SSC CPO 29/06/2024 (1st shift)
solution:
• The Banaras Session of 1905 marked a major turning point where the Indian National Congress formally endorsed the Swadeshi Movement.
  • This session was presided over by Gopal Krishna Gokhale, a moderate leader and mentor to Mahatma Gandhi.
  • The Swadeshi Movement emerged strongly in response to the Partition of Bengal (1905) by Lord Curzon.
  • Gokhale, although moderate in approach, supported constitutional reforms and economic self-reliance through Swadeshi.

Additional Information:

  • Gopal Krishna Gokhale founded the Servants of India Society in 1905 to promote Indian welfare.
  • The Swadeshi Movement called for the boycott of British goods and promotion of indigenous industries.
  • Jawaharlal Nehru, Rajendra Prasad, and Motilal Nehru became prominent much later; none were INC Presidents in 1905.
  • The Extremist-Moderate split in INC began surfacing during this period, culminating in the Surat Split (1907).

question:
The Quit India Resolution was ratified in the_________ session of Indian National Congress to launch the movement.

Matriculation Level 20/06/2024 (Shift- 1)
solution:
• The Quit India Resolution was passed and ratified during the Bombay Session of the Indian National Congress.
  • This session took place on 8 August 1942 at Gowalia Tank Maidan, also known as August Kranti Maidan.
  • The resolution called for an immediate end to British rule in India and launched the Quit India Movement.
  • It was moved by Jawaharlal Nehru and approved under the leadership of Mahatma Gandhi, who gave the iconic call: "Do or Die".

Additional Information:

  • The British government responded by arresting almost the entire INC leadership the very next day (9 August 1942).
  • This movement was also known as the August Movement.
  • Bankipur, Lucknow, and Nagpur were venues of earlier INC sessions but not associated with the Quit India Resolution.
  • Despite brutal suppression, the movement sparked mass protests and is considered a key milestone in India’s freedom struggle.

question:
In which of the following places the Indian National Congress passed the resolution of Purna Swaraj?

Matriculation Level 20/06/2024 (Shift- 4)
solution:
• The Purna Swaraj (Complete Independence) resolution was passed during the Lahore Session of the Indian National Congress in December 1929.
  • This session was presided over by Jawaharlal Nehru, marking his first time as INC President.
  • The resolution declared that India would accept nothing less than complete independence from British rule.
  • 26 January 1930 was declared as Independence Day, and it was celebrated across the country by hoisting the tricolor.

Additional Information:

  • The resolution rejected the Dominion Status offered by the British and marked a radical shift in INC's goals.
  • The Karachi Session (1931) later elaborated on the Fundamental Rights and Economic Policy of the INC.
  • Madras and Bombay hosted other sessions but were not associated with the Purna Swaraj declaration.
  • This resolution laid the groundwork for the Civil Disobedience Movement, launched in 1930.

question:
__________ was elected as the president of the third session of Indian National Congress.

Matriculation Level 24/06/2024 (Shift- 1)
solution:
• The third session of the Indian National Congress was held in Madras in 1887.
  • Badruddin Tyabji was elected as the President of this session.
  • He was the first Muslim to preside over a Congress session.
  • Tyabji was a strong advocate of Hindu-Muslim unity and supported the constitutional reform approach of the Congress in its early phase.

Additional Information:

  • The first session (1885) was held in Bombay under W.C. Bonnerjee.
  • The second session (1886) was in Calcutta, presided over by Dadabhai Naoroji.
  • KT Telang was a distinguished scholar but never became INC President.
  • Pherozeshah Mehta, known as the "Lion of Bombay", presided over the Calcutta session in 1890.
  • A.O. Hume was one of the founders of the Indian National Congress but was never its president.

question:
All India Kisan Sabha was founded in 1936 at Indian National Congress (INC) ________ Session as All India Kisan Congress.

Matriculation Level 26/06/2024 (Shift- 1)
solution:
• The All India Kisan Sabha (AIKS) was founded in April 1936 during the Lucknow Session of the Indian National Congress.
  • It was initially formed as the All India Kisan Congress, later renamed All India Kisan Sabha.
  • The founding president of AIKS was Swami Sahajanand Saraswati, a prominent peasant leader from Bihar.
  • Its primary objective was to organize peasants against zamindari exploitation, land revenue oppression, and to demand agrarian reforms.

Additional Information:

  • The Lucknow Session of INC (1936) was presided over by Jawaharlal Nehru, who was sympathetic to peasant causes.
  • The red flag became the symbol of the Kisan movement.
  • AIKS later aligned with leftist and socialist ideologies, contributing to peasant uprisings and agrarian movements in India.
  • Agra, Bombay, and Delhi hosted other INC sessions, but they were not associated with the founding of AIKS.

question:
Indian National Congress celebrated the first Independence Day in Colonial India on ____________ .

SSC Stenographer 12/10/2023 (Afternoon)
solution:
• The Indian National Congress celebrated the first Independence Day (Purna Swaraj Day) on 26 January 1930.
  • This followed the Lahore Session of December 1929, where the INC passed the Purna Swaraj Resolution, declaring Complete Independence as its ultimate goal.
  • It was decided that 26 January would be observed across India by hoisting the tricolour, public gatherings, and reading out the pledge of independence.

Additional Information:

  • This day was celebrated annually until 1947, when India gained actual independence on 15 August.
  • To honor the earlier significance, 26 January was chosen as the day to enforce the Constitution of India in 1950, making it Republic Day.
  • 2 October is celebrated as Gandhi Jayanti, not Independence Day.
  • 29 December 1929 was the date when the Lahore Session began, but the celebration was marked for 26 January.

question:
Who led the Indian National Congress at its first annual session?

SSC Stenographer 13/10/2023 (Afternoon)
solution:
• The first annual session of the Indian National Congress was held in Bombay (now Mumbai) from 28 to 31 December 1885.
  • The session was presided over by Womesh Chunder Banerjee (W.C. Banerjee).
  • He thus became the first President of the Indian National Congress.
  • The session was attended by 72 delegates from different parts of India and focused on constitutional reforms and greater Indian representation in governance.

Additional Information:

  • A.O. Hume, a retired British civil servant, was the founder and key organizer of the INC but did not preside over the session.
  • Dadabhai Naoroji presided over later sessions including 1886 (Calcutta), 1893 (Lahore), and 1906 (Calcutta).
  • Surendranath Banerjee was a prominent nationalist leader but was not associated with the 1885 session.

question:
Who was the first Woman President of Indian National Congress?

SSC MTS 08/09/2023 (2nd Shift)
solution:
• The first woman president of the Indian National Congress was Annie Besant.
  • She presided over the Calcutta Session in 1917.
  • Annie Besant was an Irish-born Theosophist, social reformer, and a strong supporter of Indian self-rule.
  • Her leadership marked a significant step toward women’s participation in Indian politics.

Additional Information:

  • Sarojini Naidu became the first Indian woman to preside over the INC in 1925 (Kanpur Session).
  • Usha Mehta was a freedom fighter known for her role in the underground Congress Radio during the Quit India Movement, but was never INC President.
  • Asaf Ali was a nationalist leader and diplomat but never presided over the INC.

question:
Which flag of the Indian National Congress was adopted in 1931?

SSC MTS 12/09/2023 (2nd Shift)
option_1: A two colour flag with charkha made by cloth
option_2: A tricolour flag made by Khadi with a Charkha symbol
option_3: One colour flag with charkha symbol
option_4: A blue colour flag made by cloth
solution:
• In 1931, the Indian National Congress adopted a tricolour flag made of Khadi featuring a charkha (spinning wheel) at its center.
  • The flag had three horizontal stripes:
    • Saffron (top) – representing courage and sacrifice
    • White (middle) – for peace and truth (with the charkha)
    • Green (bottom) – for faith and chivalry
  • The charkha symbolized self-reliance and Swadeshi movement, core principles of the freedom struggle.

Additional Information:

  • This flag served as the basis for the design of the current national flag of India, adopted in 1947, where the Ashoka Chakra replaced the charkha.
  • The flag was not the official national flag, but was used widely during protests and INC sessions.
  • The 1931 adoption clarified the color scheme and symbolism, and made the tricolour a symbol of national unity.

question:
In the 1939 Tripuri Congress Presidential Election, Sitaramayya was defeated by:

SSC MTS 13/09/2023 (1st Shift)
solution:
• In the 1939 Tripuri Session of the Indian National Congress, Subhas Chandra Bose defeated Pattabhi Sitaramayya in the presidential election.
  • Although Mahatma Gandhi supported Sitaramayya, Bose won with majority votes, reflecting growing support for his more radical and assertive stance against British rule.
  • Bose’s victory created a significant rift within the Congress leadership, especially between the moderate Gandhi faction and the radical nationalist faction.

Additional Information:

  • Subhas Chandra Bose had earlier presided over the 1938 Haripura Session.
  • After facing opposition from the Working Committee, Bose resigned in 1939 and later formed the Forward Bloc.
  • Jawaharlal Nehru and Rajendra Prasad did not contest this election.
  • This incident marked a critical moment in the ideological division within the Congress Party.

question:
The second annual session of Indian National Congress was held at which of the following places ?

SSC CHSL 11/08/2023 (2nd shift)
solution:
• The second annual session of the Indian National Congress was held in Calcutta in December 1886.
  • This session was presided over by Dadabhai Naoroji, a renowned nationalist and economic thinker.
  • It marked a significant increase in participation, with over 400 delegates, compared to 72 in the first session.

Additional Information:

  • The first session was held in Bombay (Mumbai) in 1885 under the leadership of W.C. Bonnerjee.
  • Dadabhai Naoroji later became President of the INC three times (1886, 1893, and 1906).
  • The Calcutta session helped consolidate INC as a pan-Indian platform for expressing nationalist demands.
  • Delhi and Madras hosted later sessions but were not the venue for the second session.

question:
Self-Government or 'Swaraj' as the ultimate goal of the Indian National Congress-this declaration was made by Dadabhai Naoroji in which of the following sessions of the INC ?

SSC CGL 20/07/2023 (4th shift)
solution:
• The declaration of 'Self-Government' or 'Swaraj' as the ultimate goal of the Indian National Congress was made by Dadabhai Naoroji during the Calcutta Session of 1906.
  • This was a historic moment as it marked the first formal articulation of Swaraj as a political goal by the INC.
  • Dadabhai Naoroji, also known as the “Grand Old Man of India”, presided over this session.

Additional Information:

  • The 1906 session was significant for introducing four key resolutions:
    1. Swaraj
    2. Swadeshi
    3. Boycott of British goods
    4. National Education
  • This session laid the groundwork for the growing extremist–moderate rift in the INC, which would later manifest in the Surat Split (1907).
  • The term Swaraj was defined as self-rule within the British Empire, similar to dominion status.
  • The Calcutta session thus became a turning point in India's nationalist movement.

question:
Which Session of Congress and Muslim League reached an understanding of creating a joint front against the British regime?

SSC CGL 27/07/2023 (3rd shift)
solution:
• The Lucknow Session of 1916 marked a historic agreement between the Indian National Congress and the All India Muslim League.
  • This agreement is known as the Lucknow Pact, where both parties decided to jointly demand constitutional reforms from the British government.
  • It was a rare moment of Hindu-Muslim unity during the freedom movement.

Key Points of the Lucknow Pact:

  • Separate electorates were accepted for Muslims, a key demand of the Muslim League.
  • Congress agreed to greater Muslim representation in legislatures.
  • Both parties presented a united front to the British for self-governance.
  • The pact helped bridge the gap between the Moderates and Extremists within the Congress as well.

Additional Information:

  • The Lucknow Session of the INC was presided over by Ambica Charan Mazumdar.
  • Leaders like Bal Gangadhar Tilak, Annie Besant, and Muhammad Ali Jinnah played important roles in forging this pact.
  • The agreement marked a high point in Hindu-Muslim cooperation, though it was short-lived.

question:
Which among the following sessions of Indian National Congress was the first session to be presided by a lady ?

SSC MTS 02/05/2023 (Afternoon)
solution:
• The first session of the Indian National Congress to be presided over by a woman was the Calcutta Session of 1917.
  • The session was presided over by Annie Besant, an Irish-born theosophist, educationist, and social reformer.
  • She became the first woman President of the Indian National Congress.

Additional Information:

  • Kanpur Session (1925) was presided over by Sarojini Naidu, the first Indian woman to become INC President.
  • Lahore Session (1929) was led by Jawaharlal Nehru, where the Purna Swaraj Resolution was passed.
  • Surat Session (1907) is remembered for the split between Moderates and Extremists, not for any woman president.

question:
In _________ at its Madras session, the Indian National Congress set up an All Parties Conference to draft a Constitution for India.

SSC MTS 03/05/2023 (Evening)
solution:
• In 1927, during its Madras Session, the Indian National Congress decided to set up an All Parties Conference.
  • The goal of this conference was to draft a Constitution for India, reflecting the growing national demand for self-governance.
  • This was a proactive step in response to the British government’s delay in offering constitutional reforms.

Additional Information:

  • The All Parties Conference led to the formation of a committee under Motilal Nehru, which later submitted the Nehru Report in 1928.
  • The Nehru Report was the first major Indian effort to outline a dominion status constitution for India.
  • This move signaled India's readiness for self-rule and intensified the demand for complete independence.
  • 1922, 1932, and 1915 are not linked to this development:
    • 1922: Aftermath of the Non-Cooperation Movement
    • 1932: Civil Disobedience Movement and Communal Award
    • 1915: Gandhi’s return to India

question:
The split in Indian National Congress occurred in ________ .

SSC MTS 17/05/2023 (Evening)
solution:
• The split in the Indian National Congress occurred in the year 1907 during the Surat Session.
  • The Congress was divided into two factions:
    • Moderates – led by Gopal Krishna Gokhale
    • Extremists – led by Bal Gangadhar Tilak
  • The key issue was the method of struggle against British rule—constitutional reforms vs. direct action.

Additional Information:

  • The Surat Session (1907) was held on the banks of the Tapti River in present-day Gujarat.
  • The session was marred by conflict and chaos, and no president was officially elected due to the rift.
  • Rash Behari Ghosh was initially proposed as president by the moderates.
  • This ideological split weakened the Congress for a few years and delayed united mass movements.
  • The split was somewhat healed during the Lucknow Pact of 1916, which brought moderates and extremists back together.

question:
The Indian National Congress was established when 72 delegates from all over the country met at Bombay in December _______.

SSC MTS 20/06/2023 (Morning)
solution:
• The Indian National Congress (INC) was founded in December 1885.
  • The first session was held in Bombay (now Mumbai) at Gokuldas Tejpal Sanskrit College.
  • It was attended by 72 delegates from various parts of India.
  • The session was presided over by W.C. Bonnerjee, making him the first President of the INC.

Additional Information:

  • The founding of INC was initiated by A.O. Hume, a retired British civil servant, to create a platform for Indian voices in governance.
  • The INC aimed to obtain greater Indian participation in the British Indian government through constitutional means.
  • The INC later became the principal organization leading the freedom struggle against British colonial rule.

question:
Who among the following was the President of the Indian National Congress during the 1915 session?

SSC CGL Tier II 06/03/2023
solution:
• The President of the Indian National Congress during the 1915 session was Satyendra Prasanna Sinha.
  • He was the first Indian to be elevated to the British House of Lords and also held various important positions in British India.
  • His election symbolized a continued moderate approach in the INC during this phase.

Additional Information:

  • The 1915 session was held at Bombay.
  • Satyendra Prasanna Sinha was also the first Indian Advocate General of Bengal and a member of the Viceroy’s Executive Council.
  • His leadership during the session reflected the moderate ideology of Congress before the rise of mass movements.
  • Other options:
    • Ambica Charan Mazumdar – President in 1916 (Lucknow Session).
    • Bhupendra Nath Bose – President in 1914.
    • Madan Mohan Malaviya – President in 1909 and later in 1918.

question:
How many delegates participated in the second session of Indian National Congress?

SSC CGL 07/12/2022 (2nd Shift)
solution:
• The second session of the Indian National Congress was held in Calcutta in December 1886.
  • It was presided over by Dadabhai Naoroji.
  • A total of 434 delegates participated in this session.
  • This marked a significant increase from the 72 delegates who attended the first session in 1885, showing the growing popularity and national reach of the Congress.

Additional Information:

  • The session focused on expanding the Congress's base and emphasized constitutional reforms and greater Indian involvement in governance.
  • Dadabhai Naoroji later became INC President two more times: in 1893 (Lahore) and 1906 (Calcutta).
  • The increasing number of delegates reflected the pan-Indian nature of the movement even in its early years.

question:
In which of the following sessions of the Indian National Congress did George Yule become the President in 1888?

SSC CGL 12/04/2022 (Evening)
solution:
• George Yule became the President of the Indian National Congress during its 1888 session held at Allahabad.
  • He was the first Englishman to preside over an INC session.
  • His election symbolized the early moderate approach of the Congress, aiming for cooperation and dialogue with the British government.

Additional Information:

  • George Yule was a British merchant and former Sheriff of Calcutta.
  • The INC at that time believed in gaining political rights through constitutional and peaceful methods.
  • The 1888 session helped Congress gain more national attention, especially in the British press.
  • Other relevant sessions:
    • Calcutta (1886) – President: Dadabhai Naoroji
    • Madras (1887) – President: Badruddin Tyabji
    • Bombay (1885) – First session, President: W.C. Bonnerjee

question:
In which of the following years did the resolution at the Karachi Session of the Indian National Congress dwell on how Independent India’s Constitution should look?

SSC CGL 13/04/2022 (Afternoon)
solution:
• The Karachi Session of the Indian National Congress was held in 1931, and it is most noted for passing a landmark resolution that outlined the fundamental rights and duties of citizens in independent India.
  • This session was presided over by Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel.
  • The resolution emphasized that Swaraj (independence) must guarantee:
    • Fundamental rights (equality before law, freedom of speech, religion, press)
    • Social and economic justice
    • Universal adult franchise
    • Protection of labor rights and minorities

Additional Information:

  • This session took place shortly after the execution of Bhagat Singh, Rajguru, and Sukhdev.
  • The Karachi Resolution is considered a blueprint for the future Constitution of India.
  • Other options:
    • 1928: Nehru Report drafted (but not a session about the Constitution)
    • 1945 and 1946: Pre-independence discussions began but the specific constitutional vision was first detailed in 1931.

question:
Who among the following presided over the special session of Congress in September 1923 and at the age of 35 became the youngest man to be elected as the President of the Congress?

SSC CHSL 06/08/2021 (Morning)
option_4: Maulana Abul Kalam Azad
solution:
• The special session of the Indian National Congress held in September 1923 at Delhi was presided over by Maulana Abul Kalam Azad.
  • At the age of 35, he became the youngest person ever to be elected as the President of the Indian National Congress.
  • Azad was a prominent freedom fighter, Islamic scholar, and later served as India’s first Education Minister after independence.

Additional Information:

  • Maulana Azad strongly advocated Hindu-Muslim unity and opposed the partition of India.
  • He played a leading role in movements like the Khilafat Movement and the Non-Cooperation Movement.
  • Other options:
    • Mahadev Govind Ranade – Social reformer and moderate leader, but never INC President.
    • Ram Manohar Lohia – Socialist leader, active post-independence, never INC President.
    • Bal Gangadhar Tilak – Extremist leader, INC President in 1907 (Surat) and a key figure in early nationalist politics.

question:
Who was the President of the Indian National Congress when India won its freedom in the year 1947 ?

SSC CHSL 09/08/2021 (Evening)
solution:
• When India achieved independence on 15 August 1947, the President of the Indian National Congress was J.B. Kripalani.
  • He had been elected to the post in 1946 and served through the critical transition period leading up to and including independence.
  • Kripalani played a key organizational role during the transfer of power from British rule.

Additional Information:

  • Jivatram Bhagwandas Kripalani, popularly known as Acharya Kripalani, was a senior freedom fighter and a close associate of Mahatma Gandhi.
  • He also later founded the Kisan Mazdoor Praja Party (KMPP).
  • Other leaders:
    • Abul Kalam Azad was INC President from 1940 to 1945.
    • Jawaharlal Nehru became India’s first Prime Minister, but was not INC President in 1947.
    • Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel was a senior Congress leader but never served as INC President during independence.

question:
The All-India Muslim League, popularly known as the Muslim League, was founded in _________ .

Matriculation Level 21/06/2024 (Shift- 4)
solution:
• The All-India Muslim League, commonly known as the Muslim League, was founded in the year 1906.
  • It was established on 30 December 1906 at Dacca (now Dhaka, Bangladesh).
  • The formation took place during the All India Muhammadan Educational Conference, organized by Nawab Salimullah of Dacca.

Additional Information:

  • The first president of the Muslim League was Aga Khan III.
  • Its formation was supported by the British as a counterbalance to the Indian National Congress.
  • Initially, the League aimed to safeguard the political rights of Muslims in India.
  • Later, under Muhammad Ali Jinnah, it became the leading force behind the demand for Pakistan, which was realized in 1947.

question:
The Lucknow Pact was signed in ____________ by Congress and the Muslim League to work in alliance for representative government.

SSC CPO 04/10/2023 (Afternoon)
solution:
• The Lucknow Pact was signed in the year 1916 between the Indian National Congress and the All India Muslim League.
  • It was a mutual agreement to present a united demand to the British for constitutional reforms and to work together for establishing a representative government in India.

Key Features:

  • The pact accepted the principle of separate electorates for Muslims.
  • It marked a rare moment of Hindu-Muslim unity in the freedom struggle.
  • The agreement strengthened the nationalist movement by showing British authorities a united political front.

Additional Information:

  • The Lucknow Session of Congress (1916) was presided over by Ambica Charan Mazumdar.
  • Prominent leaders involved included Bal Gangadhar Tilak, Annie Besant, and Muhammad Ali Jinnah.
  • This unity was short-lived and began to erode in later years, especially after the Khilafat Movement and the communal tensions of the 1920s.

question:
In __________ the Muslim League had moved a resolution demanding “Independent States” for Muslims in the north- western and eastern areas of the country.

SSC CHSL 20/03/2023 (4th Shift)
solution:
• In 1940, the All-India Muslim League passed a resolution demanding "Independent States" for Muslims in the north-western and eastern zones of India.
  • This historic resolution is known as the Lahore Resolution, adopted on 23 March 1940 during the League's annual session in Lahore.
  • It was presented by A.K. Fazlul Huq and later came to be known as the Pakistan Resolution.

Key Points:

  • The resolution did not explicitly use the word "Pakistan", but it laid the ideological groundwork for the demand.
  • It stated that Muslims are a separate nation and should have autonomous states where they form the majority.
  • This was a turning point in Indian politics and led directly to the partition of India in 1947.

Additional Information:

  • 1942 – The Quit India Movement was launched by the Congress.
  • 1946 – Cabinet Mission Plan and Direct Action Day (Muslim League’s call).
  • 1935 – Government of India Act passed; unrelated to Pakistan demand.

question:
Muslim League observed ______ as ‘Direct Action Day’.

SSC MTS 18/07/2022 (Evening)
solution:
• The Muslim League observed 16 August 1946 as ‘Direct Action Day’.
  • It was called to demonstrate the demand for a separate Muslim nation (Pakistan) after rejecting the Cabinet Mission Plan.
  • The call was given by Muhammad Ali Jinnah, the leader of the Muslim League.

Key Facts:

  • The day led to widespread communal riots, especially in Calcutta (now Kolkata), known as the Great Calcutta Killings.
  • The violence resulted in thousands of deaths and injuries, marking a turning point in Hindu-Muslim relations.
  • Direct Action Day showed that the partition of India was becoming inevitable due to rising communal tensions.

Additional Information:

  • The Cabinet Mission Plan (1946) had proposed a united India with groupings of provinces, but the Muslim League was not satisfied with its structure.
  • In response, the League launched Direct Action Day to assert its demand for Pakistan.
  • The Congress and Muslim League were both at odds, and this event hastened the process toward partition in 1947.

question: In which year was the Indian National Congress founded?
solution:
• The Indian National Congress (INC) was founded in the year 1885.
  • The first session was held in Bombay (now Mumbai) from 28 to 31 December 1885.
  • It was presided over by Womesh Chunder Bonnerjee (W.C. Bonnerjee).
  • A total of 72 delegates from across the country attended the session.

Additional Information:

  • The INC was founded by Allan Octavian Hume (A.O. Hume), a retired British civil servant, to provide a platform for Indians to voice their concerns.
  • Initially, the Congress aimed at moderate constitutional reforms and greater Indian representation under British rule.
  • Over time, it evolved into the principal organization leading the Indian freedom struggle.

question: Who was the first president of the Indian National Congress?
solution:
• The first President of the Indian National Congress (INC) was Womesh Chunder Bonnerjee (W.C. Bonnerjee).
  • He presided over the first session of the INC held in Bombay from 28 to 31 December 1885.
  • He was a prominent lawyer from Bengal and played a key role in the early constitutionalist phase of the Congress.

Additional Information:

  • A.O. Hume was a retired British civil servant and the founder/organizer of the INC, but not its president.
  • Dadabhai Naoroji became the INC President in 1886, and went on to preside over three sessions in total.
  • Gopal Krishna Gokhale was a senior Congress leader and moderate reformer but was never the first president.

question: The founding session of the INC was held at:
solution:
• The founding session of the Indian National Congress (INC) was held in Bombay (now Mumbai) from 28 to 31 December 1885.
  • It was originally planned to be held in Pune, but due to a plague outbreak, the venue was shifted to Bombay.
  • The session was held at Gokuldas Tejpal Sanskrit College.

Additional Information:

  • The session was presided over by W.C. Bonnerjee, who became the first President of the INC.
  • 72 delegates from different parts of India attended this historic session.
  • The INC was founded by A.O. Hume, a retired British civil servant, to create a platform for educated Indians to express their views to the colonial administration.

question: Who is known as the 'Grand Old Man of India'?
solution:
• Dadabhai Naoroji is popularly known as the "Grand Old Man of India".
  • He was one of the most prominent leaders of the early Indian nationalist movement and was among the founding members of the Indian National Congress.
  • Naoroji is also known for his Drain of Wealth Theory, which explained how Britain was economically exploiting India.

Additional Information:

  • He was the first Indian to be elected to the British Parliament in 1892 (as a Liberal Party candidate from Finsbury Central).
  • He served as the President of the Indian National Congress three times: in 1886 (Calcutta), 1893 (Lahore), and 1906 (Calcutta).
  • He was a strong advocate for self-governance and inspired future leaders like Gopal Krishna Gokhale and Mahatma Gandhi.

question: Who presided over the Surat Session of 1907, where the Congress split?
solution:
• The Surat Session of the Indian National Congress was held in 1907 in Surat (now in Gujarat).
  • The session is historically significant because it led to a split between the Moderates and the Extremists in the Congress.
  • The session was presided over by Rash Behari Ghosh, who was aligned with the moderate faction.

Key Points:

  • The split occurred mainly due to ideological differences:
    • Moderates wanted constitutional reforms through petitions and dialogue.
    • Extremists, led by leaders like Bal Gangadhar Tilak, Bipin Chandra Pal, and Lala Lajpat Rai, advocated for more direct action.
  • The Extremist group wanted Tilak to be the president, but the Moderates opposed this.
  • The session ended in chaos and disorder, and the formal split weakened the Congress for several years.

Additional Information:

  • Rash Behari Ghosh later also presided over the 1908 session.
  • The two factions only reunited in 1916 at the Lucknow Session, facilitated by the Lucknow Pact.

question: The INC split into two groups in 1907 – the Extremists and the Moderates. Who led the Extremist group?
solution:
• In the 1907 Surat Session of the Indian National Congress, the party split into two groups:
    • Moderates – who favored constitutional reforms and gradual change.
    • Extremists – who demanded immediate self-rule and were willing to adopt more assertive methods.
  • The Extremist group was led by Bal Gangadhar Tilak, along with Bipin Chandra Pal and Lala Lajpat Rai, collectively known as Lal-Bal-Pal.

Key Points:

  • Tilak’s slogan: “Swaraj is my birthright and I shall have it” became the rallying cry of the Extremists.
  • The split was primarily over the methods of attaining Swaraj (self-rule).
  • The Extremists wanted boycott of British goods, promotion of Swadeshi, and national education.
  • The Moderates were uncomfortable with this aggressive posture and insisted on constitutional agitation.

Additional Information:

  • W.C. Bonnerjee was the first INC President (1885), aligned with early moderate views.
  • Dadabhai Naoroji was a moderate leader and presided over the 1906 session.
  • Mahatma Gandhi had not yet entered mainstream Congress politics in 1907; his leadership emerged later from 1915 onwards.

question: At which session did the Congress demand 'Purna Swaraj' (complete independence)?
solution:
• The Indian National Congress made the formal demand for ‘Purna Swaraj’ (Complete Independence) at its Lahore Session in December 1929.
  • This session was presided over by Jawaharlal Nehru, marking a generational shift in INC leadership.
  • The Purna Swaraj Resolution declared that India would no longer accept dominion status under the British and would strive for full independence.

Key Highlights:

  • 26 January 1930 was declared as Independence Day, and celebrated across the country by hoisting the tricolor flag.
  • This declaration led to the launch of the Civil Disobedience Movement under Mahatma Gandhi in 1930.
  • The decision to demand complete independence marked a major ideological shift in the national movement.

Additional Information:

  • Calcutta, 1920 – Session where INC adopted Non-Cooperation Movement.
  • Karachi, 1931 – Session focused on Fundamental Rights and Gandhi-Irwin Pact.
  • Lucknow, 1916 – Known for the Lucknow Pact between Congress and Muslim League.

question: Who was the president of the Lahore session (1929) where Purna Swaraj was declared?
solution:
• The Lahore Session of the Indian National Congress was held in December 1929.
  • Jawaharlal Nehru was elected as the President of this session.
  • During this session, the historic Purna Swaraj (Complete Independence) resolution was passed.
  • It marked a generational shift in Congress leadership from the older moderates to younger leaders like Nehru.

Key Highlights:

  • 26 January 1930 was declared as Independence Day, to be observed across India.
  • The resolution stated that India would fight for full independence, rejecting dominion status.
  • This session laid the foundation for the Civil Disobedience Movement launched in 1930.

Additional Information:

  • Motilal Nehru (Jawaharlal's father) chaired the Nehru Report Committee (1928) but was not INC President in 1929.
  • Subhas Chandra Bose presided over the 1938 (Haripura) and 1939 (Tripuri) sessions.
  • Rajendra Prasad was INC President in later years (1934, 1939 interim).

question: Who was the first Muslim president of Indian National Congress?
solution:
• The first Muslim President of the Indian National Congress (INC) was Badruddin Tyabji.
  • He presided over the third session of the INC held in Madras (now Chennai) in 1887.
  • Tyabji was a prominent lawyer, reformer, and a strong advocate for Hindu-Muslim unity.

Key Points:

  • He was also one of the founding members of the INC and worked to ensure the inclusion of Muslims in the national movement.
  • Tyabji later became a judge of the Bombay High Court, making him one of the first Indian Muslims to hold such a high judicial position.
  • His presidency helped counter the British propaganda that the Congress was a Hindu-dominated body.

Additional Information:

  • Mohammad Ali (of the Ali brothers) was involved in the Khilafat Movement but never became INC president.
  • M.A. Jinnah was initially a Congress member but later led the Muslim League and demanded the creation of Pakistan.
  • Abul Kalam Azad was a later INC president and freedom fighter; he presided over the 1940–1945 sessions but was not the first Muslim president.

question: Which INC session is associated with the adoption of the resolution on Fundamental Rights and Economic Policy?
solution:
• The Karachi Session of the Indian National Congress, held in 1931, is associated with the adoption of the resolution on Fundamental Rights and Economic Policy.
  • The session was presided over by Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel.
  • This session followed the execution of Bhagat Singh, Rajguru, and Sukhdev, and took place shortly after the Gandhi-Irwin Pact.

Key Features of the Karachi Resolution:

  • Fundamental Rights:
    • Equality before law
    • Freedom of speech, association, religion, and the press
    • Universal adult franchise
    • Protection of minority rights and cultural freedoms
  • Economic Policy:
    • State ownership of key industries
    • Protection of labor rights
    • Right to a living wage and limited working hours
    • Emphasis on agrarian reforms and social justice

Additional Information:

  • The Karachi Resolution was a visionary document that laid down the social and economic goals of independent India.
  • It served as a blueprint for the future Constitution of India.

question: In which session did the Congress officially adopt the Non-Cooperation Movement under Gandhi’s leadership?
solution:
• The Indian National Congress officially adopted the Non-Cooperation Movement at its Nagpur Session in 1920.
  • This session marked the formal acceptance of Mahatma Gandhi’s strategy of non-violent non-cooperation as a method of struggle against British rule.
  • The decision was in response to the Jallianwala Bagh massacre (1919) and the Khilafat issue.

Key Highlights of the Nagpur Session (1920):

  • Presided over by C. Vijayaraghavachariar.
  • The Congress constitution was revised to include:
    • Greater emphasis on village-level participation
    • Establishment of provincial and district committees
    • Use of Hindi in Congress work
  • The Non-Cooperation Movement involved:
    • Boycott of British institutions, titles, courts, and schools
    • Promotion of swadeshi and khadi
    • Resignation from government posts

Additional Information:

  • Bombay, 1915 – Gandhi returned to India from South Africa and was welcomed into Congress.
  • Calcutta, 1917 – Focus on moderate reforms; no major resolution adopted.
  • Lahore, 1929 – Congress declared Purna Swaraj (Complete Independence).

question: At which INC session was the slogan "Swaraj is my birthright and I shall have it" emphasized?
solution:
• The slogan "Swaraj is my birthright and I shall have it" was popularized and emphasized by Bal Gangadhar Tilak at the Banaras Session of the Indian National Congress in 1905.
  • This powerful slogan became a rallying cry for the Extremist faction of the Congress and inspired nationalist fervor across India.

Key Highlights:

  • The Banaras Session (1905) marked the growing divide between the Moderates and Extremists within the Congress.
  • Tilak's assertive tone reflected the growing impatience with the Congress's moderate approach of petitions and appeals.
  • The slogan emphasized the idea that self-rule (Swaraj) was not a concession but a natural right of every Indian.

Additional Information:

  • Calcutta, 1906 – Congress adopted Swaraj as its official goal, but it was defined vaguely at that point.
  • Surat, 1907 – The Congress split into Moderates and Extremists.
  • Lucknow, 1916 – Congress and Muslim League came together in the Lucknow Pact.

question: Who presided over the 1924 Belgaum session — the only session presided by Gandhi?
solution:
• The 1924 Belgaum Session of the Indian National Congress was presided over by Mahatma Gandhi.
  • This was the only session of the Congress that Gandhi ever presided over.
  • It was held in Belgaum (in present-day Karnataka) and was a significant moment in Gandhi's leadership during the freedom struggle.

Key Highlights:

  • The session focused on:
    • Promoting Khadi and Swadeshi
    • Eradicating untouchability
    • Strengthening Hindu-Muslim unity
  • It took place during a time of internal tensions in the Congress after the Non-Cooperation Movement was suspended in 1922.
  • Gandhi used the session to call for reconciliation between Swarajists and No-Changers within the Congress.

Additional Information:

  • C.R. Das – Presided over the Gaya Session (1922).
  • Motilal Nehru – President of the 1928 Calcutta Session.
  • Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel – Presided over the Karachi Session (1931).

question: In which session was the Indian National Congress founded by A.O. Hume?
solution:
• The Indian National Congress (INC) was founded in the Bombay Session of 1885, with the initiative and support of A.O. Hume, a retired British civil servant.
  • The first session of the INC was held from 28 to 31 December 1885 at Gokuldas Tejpal Sanskrit College, Bombay.
  • It was presided over by W.C. Bonnerjee, who became the first President of the Congress.

Key Highlights:

  • The session was attended by 72 delegates from across India.
  • The objective was to create a platform where educated Indians could voice their demands to the British government in a peaceful and constitutional manner.
  • Though A.O. Hume was not the president, he played a foundational role in bringing Indian leaders together.

Additional Information:

  • Calcutta, 1886 – Second INC session; presided over by Dadabhai Naoroji.
  • Allahabad, 1887 – Third session; presided over by Badruddin Tyabji.
  • Madras, 1888 – Fourth session; presided over by George Yule, the first Englishman to do so.

question: What was the primary aim of the early Congress leaders (Moderates)?
option_3: Constitutional reforms through petitions
option_4: Immediate withdrawal of British rule
solution:
• The primary aim of the early Congress leaders, also known as the Moderates, was to bring about constitutional reforms through petitions, resolutions, and dialogue with the British government.
  • They believed in peaceful and constitutional methods to achieve political rights and better governance for Indians under British rule.

Key Features of the Moderates' Approach:

  • Used tools like petitions, speeches, and deputations.
  • Demanded:
    • Greater Indian participation in legislative councils
    • Reduction in military expenditure
    • Separation of the judiciary from the executive
    • Civil liberties such as freedom of speech and press
  • Believed in the principle of loyalty to the British Crown while seeking reforms.

Prominent Moderate Leaders:

  • Dadabhai Naoroji
  • Gopal Krishna Gokhale
  • Pherozeshah Mehta
  • W.C. Bonnerjee

Additional Information:

  • The Extremists, who emerged later, criticized the Moderates for being too soft and demanded more direct action.
  • The split between Moderates and Extremists occurred in the Surat Session (1907).

question: Who was the INC president during the Lucknow Pact (1916)?
solution:
• The Lucknow Pact was signed in 1916 between the Indian National Congress and the All India Muslim League to present a united demand for constitutional reforms to the British government.
  • The Indian National Congress session in Lucknow (1916) was presided over by Ambika Charan Majumdar.

Key Highlights:

  • The pact marked a historic instance of Hindu-Muslim unity in the national movement.
  • It agreed to:
    • Separate electorates for Muslims
    • Mutual support for political reforms
  • This session also saw the reunion of Moderates and Extremists within the Congress after the 1907 Surat split.

Additional Information:

  • Annie Besant became INC President in 1917 (Calcutta Session).
  • Bal Gangadhar Tilak played a key role in the Lucknow Pact but was not the president.
  • M.A. Jinnah was instrumental in negotiating the pact on behalf of the Muslim League, but he was not the INC president.

question: The first woman president of the Indian National Congress was:
solution:
• The first woman president of the Indian National Congress was Annie Besant.
  • She presided over the Calcutta Session in 1917.
  • Annie Besant was an Irish-born theosophist, social reformer, and staunch supporter of Indian self-rule.
  • Her election as INC President marked a significant milestone in the participation of women in Indian politics.

Additional Information:

  • Sarojini Naidu was the first Indian woman to become INC President in 1925 (Kanpur Session).
  • Aruna Asaf Ali was a prominent leader during the Quit India Movement, but never served as INC President.
  • Vijayalakshmi Pandit, sister of Jawaharlal Nehru, held several diplomatic posts but was never INC President.

question: Which session of INC was held after the withdrawal of the Non-Cooperation Movement?
solution:
• The Gaya Session of the Indian National Congress was held in 1922, shortly after the withdrawal of the Non-Cooperation Movement.
  • The Non-Cooperation Movement was called off by Mahatma Gandhi in February 1922 after the Chauri Chaura incident, where a violent mob set fire to a police station, killing 22 policemen.

Key Highlights of Gaya Session (1922):

  • Presided over by C.R. Das (Chittaranjan Das).
  • The session revealed a split within the Congress:
    • Pro-Changers (like C.R. Das and Motilal Nehru) wanted to enter legislative councils and work from within the system.
    • No-Changers (like Gandhi, Rajendra Prasad, Vallabhbhai Patel) opposed council entry and focused on constructive work like Khadi promotion, village upliftment, etc.

Additional Information:

  • Lahore, 1929 – Purna Swaraj Resolution under Jawaharlal Nehru.
  • Karachi, 1931 – Resolution on Fundamental Rights and Economic Policy.
  • Belgaum, 1924 – Only session presided over by Mahatma Gandhi.

question: Subhas Chandra Bose defeated which leader in the 1939 Tripuri Session of INC?
solution:
• In the 1939 Tripuri Session of the Indian National Congress, Subhas Chandra Bose defeated Pattabhi Sitaramayya in the election for the post of Congress President.
  • This was a significant event because Pattabhi Sitaramayya was the candidate supported by Mahatma Gandhi.

Key Highlights:

  • Despite Gandhi’s backing, Bose won, indicating a growing divide between the radical and moderate factions within the Congress.
  • After facing opposition from the Working Committee (dominated by Gandhi supporters), Bose found it difficult to function and eventually resigned from the presidency.
  • He later went on to form the Forward Bloc in 1939.

Additional Information:

  • Tripuri Session was held in Jabalpur, Madhya Pradesh.
  • The internal rift in the INC widened after this session.
  • Subhas Bose's ideology leaned towards militant nationalism and foreign alliances, in contrast to Gandhi’s non-violent approach.

question: In which year did the Indian National Congress celebrate its 50th session?
solution:
📅 The 50th session of the Indian National Congress was held in the year 1937, specifically on 27–28 December.

🏞️ It took place in Faizpur, located in the Jalgaon district of Maharashtra, and was historically significant as the first session to be held in a rural setting.

🗣️ The session was presided over by Jawaharlal Nehru, and it reflected a shift in Congress’s focus toward agrarian issues and the demands of the rural masses. The influence of the Kisan Manifesto was evident in the resolutions passed during this session.
